awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: How are Rhyolites Generated? Evaluating Models for the Volcanic-plutonic Connection in the Searchlight Magmatic System, Nevada
awd_abstract_narration:
Eruptions of high-silica rhyolite magma are explosive, violent, and potentially extremely hazardous events. However, questions of how, under what conditions, and over what timescales the magma bodies that source these eruptions are assembled remain debated. Resolving these issues is critical for understanding a variety of magmatic and crustal processes, ranging from the geochemical stratification of the crust to monitoring the volcanoes that source such dangerous eruptions for future hazards. A significant challenge to answering these questions lies in the difficulty in documenting the physical (e.g., temperature, pressure) and geochemical conditions in magmatic systems through time. Geophysical measurements on modern volcanoes can provide 'snapshots' of a magmatic system, but they cannot shed light on long-term changes that occur over tens of thousands to millions of years. One way to bridge this gap is to study ancient volcanoes where faulting and erosion have exposed both the material that erupted from the volcano and the un-erupted material that comprises the roots of these systems within the Earth's crust. Used in combination, these extrusive and intrusive deposits can be a powerful tool to understand longer-term processes. 

This project aims to investigate one such ancient volcano near Searchlight, Nevada (USA). More specifically, the PIs will produce a high-resolution (<50,000 years) temporal record spanning the magmatic system's 1-2 million year lifetime, with which they will establish the history of magma emplacement in the crust, geochemical trends, and the relative timing of the eruption(s). To do this, the researchers will utilize high-precision U-Pb zircon geochronology, whole-rock and mineral geochemistry and barometry, and thermal models. This record will shed light on the timescales over which magmas accumulate and are stored within the Earth's upper crust, the processes that occur in and affect the magma body prior to eruption, and potential eruption triggers. Funding will also support two postdoctoral researchers (1 female), research opportunities for undergraduate students at Princeton and Northeastern Universities, and participation in Princeton University's Teachers as Scholars program, which introduces local K-12 teachers to the Earth sciences and helps them in building science curricula for use in their classrooms.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Many of the largest, most explosive, and most hazardous volcanic eruptions in Earth’s history erupt rhyolitic magmas – magmas with extremely high silica (Si­­O2) contents. Understanding how, where, and over what timescales these magmas are generated, reside in the Earth’s crust, and ultimately erupt is therefore critically important for understanding future volcanic hazards.

Some studies suggest that high SiO2 magmas form through crystallization of a lower SiO2 magma. As crystallization proceeds, the magma between the crystals becomes increasingly SiO2-rich. This high SiO2 magma is then separated from the crystals and erupts, leaving behind a crystal residue. The result is that erupted crystal-poor, high-SiO2 rhyolite magmas (volcanic rocks) are related to un-erupted crystal-rich, lower SiO2 granites and granodiorite magmas (plutonic rocks). If this is the case, then studying silicic volcanic and plutonic rocks of the same geologic age in the same magmatic system can help inform on the questions noted above. The Searchlight Magmatic System (Nevada, USA), which is comprised of the Highland Range volcanic sequence and Searchlight pluton, is a rare location where volcanic and plutonic rocks of the same geologic age are exposed at the Earth’s surface. Previous research also suggests that at least some of the erupted Highland Range rhyolites are related to the unerupted Searchlight pluton granites and granodiorites.

In this project, a graduate student from an underrepresented group in the Earth sciences spearheaded our research to explore the volcanic-plutonic relationship in the Searchlight Magmatic System in more detail. Specifically, we aimed to determine the residence depths and times of the rhyolitic magmas that erupted. To determine depths, we employed barometers that utilize the composition of glasses (quenched magmas) surrounding and contained in crystals. Our results suggest the magmas that erupted came from approximately 2-4 km depth, equivalent to the depth of the middle unit of the Searchlight pluton. The volatile (H2O, CO2) and hydrogen isotope compositions of glass inclusions in quartz crystals also suggest that there may have been two different sources for the Highland Range rhyolites.

To determine how long the rhyolitic magmas existed in an eruptible state in the crust before erupting, we capitalized on crystal zoning – tree ring-like features that form in crystals as they grow and sample changes in the magma through time. Diffusion acts to eradicate crystal zoning when the temperature is high (i.e., in a hot magma before erupting) and slows to a negligible rate when the crystal gets cold (i.e., after eruption and cooling on Earth’s surface). Zoning that doesn’t disappear before eruption can be used to understand how much time a crystal spent in the magma prior to eruption. Using this technique, diffusion chronometry, we learned that the magmas that produced the Highland Range rhyolite eruptions resided in the crust for a few centuries to millennia before erupting.

The results of our project support the volcanic-plutonic model, and they add new dimensions to our understanding of the Searchlight magmatic system in particular. Our timescale results are also notable in that they are consistent with other studies of much larger rhyolitic eruptions. This suggests that the size of an eruption is not necessarily related to the amount of time the magma sits in the crust before erupting. Finally, this project supported early-career researchers (assistant professor, graduate student, undergraduate student) from underrepresented groups in the Earth sciences and their engagement with K-12 students in the US on topics related to volcanoes and Earth science through virtual and in-person programs (e.g., Bay Area Science Festival).
